title: Introduction to Stocks and Short Selling
headline: Learn more about stocks and shares, how they are valued, and how short selling of stocks works, with this free course.
description: This free online course will teach you the basics of stocks and short selling. Companies often issue stocks to raise money and grow. When you purchase a company's stock, you are purchasing a small piece of that company. Normally, you buy stocks in the hopes that they will increase in worth - but how can you profit if the stocks you bought decline in price? The answer is shorting. This course will teach you all about how shorting works.

courseDescription:
Stocks are also known as shares or equity and are a type of security that signifies proportionate ownership in the issuing corporation. This entitles the stockholder to that proportion of the corporation's assets and earnings. This course will discuss how you essentially become a partial or part owner of a company when you buy stock or shares from that company. You will also learn what makes them different to bonds, which do not make you part-owner of the company involved.

Shorting stock involves the sale of stock that a seller does not own, or shares that the seller has taken on loan from a broker. This course will discuss why short sellers take on these transactions. You will learn that they act on mere speculations that a stock's price is headed downward and that if they sell the stock, they'll be able to buy it back at a lower price at some point in the future. You will also learn the importance of selling high and buying low.

The stock market plays an important role in many countries economies, both from the point of view of nations' industries, investors, and governments. This means that people who have a strong understanding of the stock market are in high demand around the world. If you are interested in getting to know more about this incredible industry, check out this course today and start learning something that can make a real difference to your bank account!

modules.description: This module, Introduction to Stocks and Short Selling, outlines the fundamental principles of Stocks and Short Selling by defining what stocks and shares are and how they are valued. This module also identifies the key principles of short selling by outlining how to borrow stocks that you do not own, what obligations you have to the original owner of the stocks and how to cover your short where you return the stocks after buying them back, hopefully, for less than the cost when you sold them.

• The key points from this module are:
  • When you buy stock or you buy shares in a company you are essentially becoming a partial, or part owner, of the company.
  • Key terms in this module include:
    • Assets: can be regarded as things that provide value or some type of future benefit. For example, cash is an asset because it can be exchanged for things we need in the future. Accounts receivable and stock can be considered other types of assets. 
    • Liabilities: usually refer to something you owe such as a debt or loan from the bank.
    • Current liabilities: are typically things that they have to pay in cash within the next year. 
    • Average volume: refers to the average volume of shares sold or exchanged per day. 
    • Book value share: can be calculated by dividing a company’s total assets by the total number of shares in the company.
    • Market cap: essentially indicates what the market is currently willing to pay per company share.
  • Traditionally in the stock market, on the long side you want to buy low, sell high, however, when you're short selling, you're doing the same thing, but you're doing it in reverse – you want to sell high and buy low.
